stem: A client with a T6 spinal cord injury is admitted to the intensive care unit. At 16:00, the client reports a severe headache and blurred vision. Based on the data provided, which of the following interventions should the nurse implement *FIRST*?

options.text: Elevate the head of the bed to at least 45 degrees.
options.feedback: Elevating the head of the bed helps to lower blood pressure and is a crucial first step in managing autonomic dysreflexia.

options.text: Assess for bladder distension or bowel impaction.
options.feedback: Bladder distension and bowel impaction are common triggers for autonomic dysreflexia. Assessing for these is essential for identifying and addressing the underlying cause.

options.text: Check the Foley catheter for kinks or obstruction.
options.feedback: A kinked or obstructed Foley catheter can cause bladder distension, triggering autonomic dysreflexia. Ensuring proper catheter function is a priority.

options.text: Administer hydralazine IV per physician's order.
options.feedback: Hydralazine is an antihypertensive medication that will help lower the client's dangerously high blood pressure. This is an important intervention in managing autonomic dysreflexia.

options.text: Monitor blood pressure every 5 minutes after administering hydralazine.
options.feedback: Frequent blood pressure monitoring is crucial after administering hydralazine to assess its effectiveness and prevent hypotension.

options.text: Administer docusate sodium PO per the medication administration record.
options.feedback: While constipation can be a trigger for autonomic dysreflexia, addressing the immediate hypertensive crisis takes priority. Docusate is a stool softener and will take time to work.

itemContext.sbar: S: Robert Jameson, a 42-year-old male with a T6 spinal cord injury, admitted to ICU at 15:00 for suspected autonomic dysreflexia. He reports a severe, throbbing headache and blurred vision. B: Patient has a history of recurrent UTIs and manages his bowel program independently at home. Last bowel movement was two days ago. A: At 16:00, BP is 210/110 mmHg, HR 52 bpm. Skin is flushed above the T6 injury level and pale below. Patient is diaphoretic and reports feeling anxious. O: Continuous cardiac monitoring shows sinus bradycardia. SpO2 is 98% on room air. A Foley catheter is in place, draining clear yellow urine. Neurological assessment reveals no new deficits. Current orders include PRN hydralazine 10mg IV for SBP > 180 mmHg and prepare for possible bowel disimpaction.

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct: Elevate the head of the bed to at least 45 degrees. This helps to reduce cerebral blood pressure by promoting venous return and decreasing intracranial pressure. Assess for bladder distension or bowel impaction. These are the most common triggers for autonomic dysreflexia due to noxious stimuli below the level of the spinal cord injury. Check the Foley catheter for kinks or obstruction. A full bladder can trigger autonomic dysreflexia by causing increased pressure and stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system. Administer hydralazine IV per physician's order. This medication is a direct-acting peripheral arterial vasodilator that will help lower the blood pressure quickly. Monitor blood pressure every 5 minutes after administering hydralazine. Frequent monitoring is essential to assess the effectiveness of the intervention and prevent hypotension, which can occur rapidly with hydralazine administration.
rationale.incorrect: Administer docusate sodium PO per the medication administration record. While constipation can be a trigger for autonomic dysreflexia, addressing the immediate hypertensive crisis takes priority. Docusate is a stool softener and will take time to work, making it unsuitable for immediate management. The priority is to lower the blood pressure and identify/remove the triggering stimulus.
clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention to prevent stroke, seizure, or death.
Always address the most life-threatening problems first (ABCs and blood pressure).
Elevating the head of the bed is a simple and effective first step to lower blood pressure.
Hypertension and bradycardia are classic signs of autonomic dysreflexia, often accompanied by headache, flushing, and sweating above the level of injury.

questionTrap.trap: The incorrect option focusing on docusate sodium may seem appropriate because bowel impaction is a common trigger. However, the immediate priority is to address the dangerously high blood pressure, which poses an immediate threat to the patient's well-being.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize interventions based on the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) and the severity of the patient's symptoms. In this case, the dangerously high blood pressure necessitates immediate action to prevent stroke or other complications. Addressing the bowel issue is important but secondary to stabilizing the blood pressure.

mnemonic.title: S.I.T. U.P.
mnemonic.expansion: Signs (Monitor BP closely); Identify (and remove the Cause); Treat BP (with antihypertensives); Urinary (Check catheter for kinks/obstruction); Position (Elevate HOB to 45 degrees)
